title: 110_hr5672
content: The "Women's Business Ownership Act of 2008" establishes the "National Commission on Women's Business Ownership" with specific duties outlined for the Commission. The "National Commission on Women's Business Ownership" is required to review the status of women business owners, the role of the Federal Government in aiding them, and data collection procedures. Based on its review, the Commission must recommend new private-sector initiatives for management and technical assistance, ways to increase access to credit for women in business, and ways to enhance procurement opportunities for women business owners. For the purposes of this Act, a business is considered owned by a woman if the sole owner is a woman, or if one-half or more of the partners are women, or if 50 percent or more of the stock is owned by women. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of nine members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader. Appointments must be individuals with specific qualifications and not affiliated with the Federal Government or Congress. The Commission consists of nine members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader. Appointments must have specific qualifications and not be affiliated with the Federal Government or Congress. Members appointed under each paragraph must adhere to certain criteria regarding political party, gender, and small business ownership. Consideration should be given to achieving geographical balance in appointments. Members serve for the life of the Commission, unless they become Federal Government employees or Members of Congress. Members of the Commission serve without pay but are entitled to reimbursement for expenses. Five members constitute a quorum, and the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are designated by the President. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson of the Commission is appointed by the President and serves for the life of the Commission. The Commission must meet at least four times a year, with meetings called by a majority of its members. The Director and staff of the Commission are appointed by the President and serve for the life of the Commission. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, who can appoint additional personnel. The Director and staff may be appointed without certain regulations and paid within specified limits. The Commission may also procure temporary services as needed. The Commission may detail personnel from any agency to assist in its duties on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the power to detail personnel from any agency to assist in its duties on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and access information from government agencies to carry out its duties under this Act. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and they can use the United States mails. Administrative support is provided by the Administrator of General Services. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis as requested. The Commission will provide interim and final reports to the President and Congress, with recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission will terminate upon submitting its final report. Appropriations are authorized as needed for the Commission's activities.
